Name: Juelich atlas
Description: Probabilistic cytoarchitectonic atlas based on microscopic and quantitative histological examination of ten human post-mortem brains. The atlas contains 52 grey matter structures and 10 white matter structures defined by cyto- and myelo-architectonic segmentations. Maps were 3D reconstructed and spatially normalized into MNI space. The atlas is part of the Julich-Brain project, a continuously expanding ('living') atlas with over 200 brain regions.
Curators: C. and O. Vogt Institute for Brain Research
HowToAcknowledge: Please cite: Eickhoff et al. (2005) NeuroImage 25(4):1325-35; Amunts et al. (2020) Science 369(6506):988-992. For individual structures, cite the relevant mapping publications. Data kindly provided by the Research Centre Jülich and Simon Eickhoff.
License: FSL License - Non-commercial use only. Commercial use requires permission from Forschungszentrum Jülich GmbH. Contact: S.Eickhoff@fz-juelich.de
Funding: Helmholtz Association Portfolio Theme 'Supercomputing and Modeling for the Human Brain', European Union Seventh Framework Programme (FP7/2007-2013, Human Brain Project), European Union's Horizon 2020 Research and Innovation Programme (grant agreements 604102, 785907, 945539)
DerivedFrom: Histological examination of 10 post-mortem human brains (5 male, 5 female) with cyto- and myelo-architectonic segmentations
